children.value: Can be used to "name" shader modules, making them available to
using module names rather than the module definitions.
Note: Can defeat three-shaking of unused shader modules (affects size of application JavaScript bundle).
Takes a list of shader module names and an object with options, and creates a combined uniform object that contains all necessary uniforms for all the modules injected into your shader.

Takes the source code of a vertex shader and a fragment shader, and a list of modules, defines, etc. Outputs resolved source code for both shaders, after adding prologue, adding defines, importing and transpiling modules, and injecting any shader fragments).
for the shader, will be used to inject shader names (using
) if not already present in the source.
(Object) - a map of key/value pairs representing custom
s to be injected into the shader source
(Array) - list of shader modules (either objects defining the module, or names of previously registered modules)
- a map with all resolved modules, keyed by name

Creates a shader hook function that shader modules can injection code into. Shaders can call these functions, which will be no-ops by default. If a shader module injects code it will be executed upon the hook function call. This mechanism allows the application to create shaders that can be automatically extended by included shader modules.
followed by the name and arguments of the function, e.g.

. Hook name without arguments
will also be used as the name of the shader hook
(optional): code always included at the beginning of a hook function
(optional): code always included at the end of a hook function
Define a code injection for a particular hook function (defined by
) and shader module. The injection code will be inserted into the hook function whenever the shader module is included.
: the name of the module for which the injection is being defined
: the shader hook to inject into. This can be a hook function defined by

or a predefined injection key (see below),
prefixed by

(optional): the priority with which to inject code into the shader hook. Lower priority numbers will
be injected first
Injected at the very beginning of main function
Injected at the very end of main function
Injected at the very beginning of main function
Injected at the very end of main function
Shader module code injections involve three steps:
Defining a shader hook function using
Calling the hook function in a shader
Defining hook code injections for particular modules
For example, if the application wanted to automatically enable picking color filtering when the
module is included in a program, first the shader hook would be defined:
function, the new hook function would called as follows:
And the injection for the picking module would be defined as follows:
If the picking module were included, the function
would be updated to modify the input color. Without the picking module, the function would remain a no-op. The

ensures the injection always
appears last in the hook function, which is necessary for picking color filtering to work correctly.
Injecting to a predefined hook would be done as follows:
argument that contains a map of:
values representing code to be injected. This can be either a simple string or an object containing the
Injection at the moment only allows code to be added, not replaced.

At the moment the implementation for injection are fairly simple. They depend on the shader code being well organized. For instance they require that the main function must come last in the app shader. In case of issues, try to make sure that line breaks, spacing etc are natural.
